profile.name: mrdoob
profile.bio: Building things for the web. Creator of @threejs. Exploring new frontiers in 3D & immersive experiences. Always learning, always shipping. 🚀 WebGL enthusiast.

tweets.content: Diving deep into WebGPU compute shaders this week. The power is incredible, but oh boy, debugging feels like talking directly to the metal sometimes. #WebGPU #graphicsdev
Just merged a small PR for a community fix on a component in my side project. Always appreciate thoughtful contributions, no matter the size! Keep the PRs coming. #opensource
Huge respect for maintainers who take the time to write excellent documentation. It's often overlooked but makes such a massive difference for adoption and community engagement.
We keep chasing the 'perfect' DX with new build tools and frameworks, but often overlook how complex we make the end product for users. Simplicity scales better than layers of abstraction.
Building a small interactive demo using WebGL2 compute shaders for fluid dynamics. Pretty raw, but seeing the particles flow is mesmerizing. Still need to optimize a lot. #gamedev #webgl
Glad to see more companies actively supporting open source maintainers. A healthy ecosystem benefits everyone. It's more than just using the code; it's investing in the community. 🙏
Just introduced a bug that only manifests itself on Tuesdays, when the moon is waxing crescent, and the user has exactly 3 tabs open. Peak dev moment.
Experimenting with a custom shader for procedural texture generation. The iterative process of tweaking values and seeing the immediate visual feedback is addictive. #creativecoding
Successfully refactored a particularly gnarly section of legacy code today. The feeling of untangling spaghetti is uniquely satisfying. Time for a celebratory coffee.
Every major tech shift feels like a return to fundamental principles but with new tools. From assembly to high-level, then back to web assembly. The cycle continues.
Another new JavaScript runtime announced? Don't get me wrong, competition is good, but the ecosystem feels like it's perpetually in beta. Still, curious to see what it brings.
Unpopular opinion: Sometimes, a well-written `if/else` block is clearer and more maintainable than a hyper-abstracted, functional-pipeline-magical-monad chain. Readability > cleverness.
My code works perfectly on my machine. *My machine* being a highly optimized, custom setup with half the browser extensions disabled and a direct LAN connection. YMMV.
My brain when trying to remember a specific CSS property vs. my brain when remembering a random meme from 2012. Priorities, right?
Debugging JavaScript feels like being a detective in a house where everything is technically labeled 'undefined' and the culprit keeps changing its disguise.
The push for everything-as-a-service sometimes abstracts away too much. Understanding the underlying infrastructure is crucial, even if you don't *always* need to manage it yourself.
Good design isn't just about aesthetics; it's about building systems that are intuitive to use and maintain. That applies equally to APIs and user interfaces, maybe even more so to code.

The pendulum of full-stack vs. specialized roles swings constantly. I think hybrid developers with deep expertise in *one* area, but broad understanding across the stack, are becoming the most valuable.
